courseDescription: Introduction to criminology as a science, including the study of crime, criminals, and society's response to them.

A study of social response to criminal behavior as cases move through the machinery of justice.  Describes the interdependence of crime statistics, law enforcement, criminal courts, and correctional procedures for purposes of analyzing the entire system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of criminal law and procedures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with law enforcement officials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the interdependence of crime statistics, law enforcement, criminal courts, and correctional procedures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and coordinating various aspects of the criminal justice system

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  Special honors section of CRJSÂ 215S.

courseTitle: Law and the Criminal Justice System
courseDescription: The course covers both substantive and procedural law related to the definitions, investigations, processing and punishment of crimes.  It is meant to provide the students with an overall understanding of the articulation between law and the criminal justice system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of substantive and procedural law
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with law enforcement and legal professionals
Collaboration with criminal justice system stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for improving justice system processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing legal documentation and case files
Leading discussions on legal reforms and policy changes

courseDescription: This course will provide students with an overview of computer-related crimes and how law enforcement officials investigate them. The course begins by describing the environment that has been created through information and communication technologies, and how this new environment facilitates different types of behavior. The course then moves into defining and describing the different types of computer-related crimes, the techniques used by officials, and the legal issues inherent in combating cybercrime.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with investigation techniques in cybercrime cases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with law enforcement officials during investigations
Collaboration with team members in cybercrime cases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of information related to cybercrimes
Problem-solving in complex legal issues within cybercrime cases
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in managing and coordinating resources for cybercrime prevention

courseDescription: A study of juvenile misbehavior in the contemporary community, its nature, extent, treatment, and control, including juvenile court procedure and philosophy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding in juvenile interactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing root causes of juvenile delinquency
Developing treatment plans for at-risk youth
Evaluating effectiveness of juvenile justice programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with community resources for juvenile support
Leading group therapy sessions for young offenders
Implementing strategies for juvenile behavior improvement

courseDescription: Examines the history of prisons and jails, their formal and informal organization, their effects on individuals, and issues and philosophies of penal reform.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with correctional staff and supervisors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing and implementing reform strategies in prisons

courseDescription: Examines the history, law, administration and social setting of probation, parole and other noninstitutional sentencing alternatives.  Also explores nontraditional alternatives to criminal adjudication such as arbitration and diversion programs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of probation and parole laws
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients and stakeholders
Building rapport with individuals under supervision
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of individual needs for rehabilitation
Evaluation of community resources for reintegration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Collaboration with community organizations for support services

courseDescription: The organization of security systems in public and private agencies and institutions.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in emergency response situations

courseDescription: Examines the creation, use and effectiveness of formal and informal mechanisms of social control for both criminal and noncriminal deviant behavior.  Cross-cultural comparisons are given special emphasis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal systems and procedures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of social control mechanisms
Critical evaluation of formal and informal mechanisms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and implementing social control measures

courseDescription: This course examines the historical and philosophical foundations of the death penalty in the United States, the Supreme Court case precedent that has effectively narrowed its modern application, and the contentious issues that surround Americaâs most severe punishment. Topics will include the moral/legal arguments surrounding the death penalty; the legal process of capital cases; the racial, ethnic, socioeconomic, and gender disparities that exist in death sentencing and executions; recent trends and scholarly evidence related to capital punishment; reasons for continued support; and the movement toward abolition.

Examines the role of police in a free society. Police functions, subculture, community relations and decision making receive special attention.  Problems such as police corruption, violence and the methods by which society attempts to control police behavior are also discussed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating police behavior in various scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a diverse team of law enforcement professionals

courseDescription: Examines the role of women as offenders, victims and employees of the criminal justice system. Theories of female criminality and the treatment of female offenders are explored.  Attention is given to the victimization of women, specifically wife abuse and rape, problems of minority women, and the impact of current legislation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis for criminal justice data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interviewing skills for criminal justice professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating treatment programs for female offenders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing community outreach events for minority women

courseDescription: Learning appropriate terminology to discuss LGBTQ individuals, as well as a review of the social issues facing these populations, including damaging cultural stereotypes. Critically exploring the history of interactions between LGBTQ communities and agents of formal control, such as schools and the police, including responses to bullying and bias crimes. Interrogating how changing political and social contexts affect policy regarding formal responses to LGBTQ communities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of social media impact on LGBTQ issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective terminology usage in LGBTQ discussions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing responses to bullying and bias crimes
Evaluating policy changes affecting LGBTQ communities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing events or campaigns for LGBTQ awareness

courseDescription: This course will describe and explain corporate, state-corporate, government (state) crime and crimes of globalization from sociological and criminological perspectives.  Although the course will deal with the general topic of white collar crime, the specific focus will be on organizational offenders such as business corporations, government, state agencies and international finance organizations.

A critical exploration of applying geographic information system (GIS) to view, understand, question, interpret, and visualize social science and crime data that reveal relationships, patterns, and trends. Students will learn to 1) frame a research question or hypothesis from a location-based perspective; 2) collect, create and examine geographically referenced demographic, social, and criminological data; 3) learn to use GIS mapping software to visualize, manage and analyze this data in order to investigate the relationship between geographic, demographic, social and criminological variables; and 4) arrive upon decisions and conclusions and communicate these via the creation of publishable maps.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using GIS mapping software
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in social science and crime data
Analyzing relationships between geographic and demographic variables
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in GIS data analysis

courseTitle: Organized Crime: A Survey of Domestic and World-Wide Organized Crime Activities
courseDescription: A broad survey of the history and consequences of organized crime in the United States and the world. Special focus will be directed at the economic, social and developmental effects of organized criminal activities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis of organized crime data
Understanding encryption methods used by criminal organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of findings on organized crime
Collaboration with law enforcement agencies for data sharing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of organized crime information
Developing strategies to combat organized crime
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a task force against organized crime
Organizing data on criminal networks for analysis

courseDescription: Sociological examination of film as an art form, an industry, and a social institution. Major topics include socialization through film, how oneâs unique socialization affects the film experience, social inequality (racism/ethnocentrism/sexism/ageism) as exhibited in film, and as they occur within the film industry, film as an educational tool, gender roles as exhibited in film and perpetuated within the film industry, film and copycat crime, crime in the film industry, portrayal of crime in film, international cinema and globalization.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of film industry technology trends
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Analyzing and discussing social issues portrayed in films
Effective communication of sociological concepts through film analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of social inequality themes in films
Identifying and analyzing gender stereotypes in film industry practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on societal implications of films
Organizing film screenings and discussions on social issues

courseDescription: This course focuses on the effect of crime on communities and the ways in which communities affect crime.  The class considers both ethnographic community studies as well as larger-scale demographic analysis.

This course seeks to evaluate issues central to the study of modern gangs, such as gang definitions, prevalence, proliferation, migration, formation, histories, and gang/gang member characteristics. Another objective is to understand why and how young people both join and leave their gangs and explore how gang structure and organization can influence gang and gang member behavior, including their involvement in violence, other illegal acts, their victimization, and the gendered experiences of female gang members. Students will also review assess policies and efforts regarding gang prevention, intervention, and suppression and distinguish between stereotypes/myths and realities about gangs and gang members based on empirical research and theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Characteristics analysis of gangs and gang members
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with young gang members for insights
Communicating effectively with gang intervention professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Distinguishing between gang stereotypes and realities based on research
Critical assessment of gang member behavior patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group projects on gang research
Organizing presentations on gang prevention efforts

courseDescription: This course allows students to volunteer to work in an agency related to their major.  Students must volunteer for 50 hours per course credit.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital communication platforms for work purposes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a work setting
Conflict resolution in a professional environment
Networking with professionals in the field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing challenges in the workplace
Creative problem-solving in a professional context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for meeting project deadlines
Task delegation and coordination with team members

courseDescription: This course explores state crime from a sociological and criminological perspective. It examines historical and current cases of governmental crime at home and abroad. It also explores the intertwinement of states with other states, corporations, and, when applicable, international financial institutions as well as their roles in facilitating or constraining acts of state crime. Finally, the class discusses the problems of control, domestically and internationally.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using criminological perspectives to understand state crime
Exploring intertwinement of states with other entities in facilitating or constraining state crime
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing state crime issues with peers
Presenting findings on governmental crime cases
Engaging in class debates on state crime control problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of governmental crime information
Identifying patterns in state crime data
Analyzing the impact of international financial institutions on state crime
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on state crime topics
Organizing research on historical and current cases of state crime

courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the approaches and practices of crime prevention. In addition, the course discusses primary, secondary, and tertiary crime prevention measures aimed at reducing or eliminating crime. Finally, the course addresses research and information on many aspects of crime prevention, including the physical environment and crime, neighborhood crime prevention, and crime in schools.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Public speaking on crime prevention strategies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk assessment for crime prevention measures
Analyzing crime data for pattern recognition

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors or for elective credit within a major. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Database querying for criminal data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective report writing for law enforcement
Conflict resolution in criminal justice settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Case study analysis in criminal investigations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in law enforcement operations

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors or for elective credit within a major. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective report writing for law enforcement
Conflict resolution in criminal justice settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Case study analysis for legal decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for law enforcement operations

courseDescription: Examines a variety of forms of violence from suicide, child abuse, rape and family violence, terrorism, torture, death squads and the death penalty and hate violence.  Explores the circumstances, rationalizations, patterns, explanations and effects on survivors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital forensics for investigating violent crimes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy in dealing with survivors of violence
Effective communication with diverse stakeholders in violence prevention
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing strategies to prevent violence in communities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating and implementing policies to address violence
Managing teams in crisis intervention situations

courseTitle: Violence in the World of Children
courseDescription: This child-centered course examines the interaction of adults in violent conflict with the world of children, children's experience of violence and its meaning in the lives of children.  Topics include: valuing children, violence toward children in culture, families, and schools; child physical and sexual abuse and neglect; gangs, violent communities and children and war.  The effects of childhood experiences of violence, children's coping with violence, and alternatives to violence are also developed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding cultural impacts on violence towards children
Research methodologies related to violence in children
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy towards children in violent situations
Effective communication with children about violence
Building trust with children affected by violence
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying signs of violence in children
Developing intervention strategies for children in violent environments
Analyzing the impact of violence on children's development
Assessing the effectiveness of violence prevention programs for children
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading advocacy campaigns for children's rights
Coordinating support services for children exposed to violence
Creating trauma-informed care plans for children
Developing community programs to address violence against children

courseDescription: This course will focus on the intersection between digital forensics and the criminal justice system, namely how digital forensics is understood and applied to key criminal justice, constitutional and statutory considerations within the criminal justice system.  Students will explore such topics as the nature and types of cybercrime; search and seizure principles in the digital world; finding, handling and maintaining chain of custody of digital evidence; interviewing individuals relating to digital evidence and related activities; and testifying in court about digital evidence matters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Chain of custody procedures for digital evidence
Interviewing techniques for digital evidence collection
Search and seizure principles in digital investigations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of technical concepts to non-technical audience
Interviewing individuals for digital evidence collection
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing digital evidence for investigative purposes
Identifying and addressing challenges in digital evidence collection
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Maintaining chain of custody for digital evidence

courseDescription: This course tackles two major cyber law subjects. The first part of the course examines various U.S. laws and legal considerations that impact the digital and cyberspace worlds from traditional civil, and to a lesser extent, traditional criminal perspectives. The second part will familiarize cyber operations professionals about the extent of and limitations on their authorities to ensure operations in cyberspace are in compliance with U.S. law, regulations, directives and policies. The course will also introduce students to miscellaneous cybersecurity topics such as the Federal Acquisition Requirements. Cross-listed with CYSEÂ 406 and CPDÂ 406.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal considerations in cyberspace
Compliance with U.S. law in cyber operations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of legal concepts in cyberspace
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of legal implications in cyberspace
Analyzing limitations on authorities in cyberspace operations
Problem-solving in compliance with U.S. law
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in ensuring legal compliance in cyber operations
Organizing and managing cyber law projects
Decision-making in legal and cybersecurity contexts

courseDescription: This course focuses on the research on child maltreatment abuse internationally, in particular on the most common types of child abuse and neglectâi.e., perpetrated by parents, family members.  The negative effects of child abuse and neglect are associated subsequently with every social problem from poverty, teenage motherhood, substance abuse, violent crime, domestic violence, and mental health problems, to ill-healthâfrom cancer to diabetes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding common types of child abuse and neglect
Identifying negative effects of child abuse and neglect on social problems
Knowledge of international child protection laws and policies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders in different countries
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of child abuse data
Identifying root causes of child maltreatment
Developing strategies to prevent child abuse internationally
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating international efforts to combat child abuse
Leading advocacy campaigns for child protection rights globally
Collaborating with NGOs and government agencies to address child maltreatment issues

courseDescription: A study of the law concerning children from a children's rights perspective. The rights of children in the US will be compared to other nations with special emphasis being placed on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of child rights laws in the US and internationally
Understanding of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of legal concepts related to children's rights
Collaboration with individuals from diverse backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of children's rights laws across different countries
Critical evaluation of legal documents and treaties regarding children's rights
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on legal implications for children's well-being

courseDescription: The purpose of this interdisciplinary course is to introduce students to the ways in which computers are involved in the commission and the investigation of crime. Students will learn the fundamentals of cryptography and steganography and the tools used to perform these activities. Students will also use forensic software to identify, gather, and verify relevant digital evidence. Cross-listed with CYSEÂ 409.

Methods and programs which attempt to correct the behaviors of juvenile delinquents and adult criminal offenders are explored.  Treatment strategies employed in both community and institutional settings are examined.  Techniques of classification and the role of the correctional worker are also discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with juvenile delinquents and adult offenders
Building rapport with clients in correctional settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing behavior patterns for classification purposes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of correctional workers

courseDescription: An overview of the role of all of the actors in the American courtroom, the interaction of these actors and the effect of social forces on their behavior.  Includes prosecutor, plaintiff and defense lawyers, judges, juries, eye witnesses, expert witnesses, and court staff.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing case strategies based on evidence

courseDescription: A review of the literature, law and practical materials that cover the American jury system from the creation of the master list through the verdict.  Includes history, social context and jury selection.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a legal team during trials

courseDescription: A critical exploration of media portrayals of crime and criminal justice.  News and entertainment genres are examined.  Connections between the mass media and crime, culture, politics, society, and individual behavior receive special attention.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing media impact on culture and society
Identifying media biases in crime reporting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on media ethics and crime coverage

courseDescription: This is a class about the role of nonhuman animals in society. Animals are used to entertain, to do work, to provide companionship, to provide food, and more. In this class, we discuss the causes and consequences of both individual and institutional animal abuse. Society's relation to wildlife is also an important component and includes poaching, sport and trophy hunting, and society's reaction to wolves, coyotes, and wild horses in the West. Cross-listed with SOCÂ 419.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of animal welfare issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions to reduce animal cruelty
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing events to raise awareness about animal rights

courseDescription: A study of various definitions and forms of deviant behavior, theoretical explanations of causes of deviant behavior, and the impact of deviant behavior on society and the individual.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of various forms of deviant behavior
Knowledge of theoretical explanations of causes of deviant behavior
Data analysis skills in identifying deviant patterns
Research methodologies for studying deviant behavior
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and present findings on deviant behavior
Effective communication with individuals displaying deviant behavior
Empathy and understanding towards individuals engaged in deviant behavior
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of deviant behavior theories
Analyzing the impact of deviant behavior on society and individuals
Identifying strategies for intervention and prevention of deviant behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on deviant behavior topics
Collaborating with others in studying and addressing deviant behavior

courseDescription: A study of the nature, development, and utilization of public policy within agencies of the criminal justice system. Topics include policy formulation, constraints on policy makers, influence of constituencies, and the role of research information. Case studies of issues such as crime control, prison overcrowding, police use of deadly force, the death penalty and parole guidelines will be undertaken.

courseTitle: Juvenile Justice: Issues, Policy, and Practice
courseDescription: This course will provide an overview of significant policy issues in contemporary juvenile justice. The first objective of the course is to examine the nature, extent, treatment and control of juvenile delinquency. The second objective of the course is to discuss the history of juvenile justice policy reform and evidence-based practices. Third, the course will identify and analyze a number of key juvenile justice policy issues, including: mental health, gender disparities, disproportionate minority contact (DMC), trauma, adult transfer and certification, as well as policies and practices for preventing and responding to delinquency.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of juvenile justice policies
Identification of key issues in juvenile justice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on juvenile justice reforms

courseDescription: An in-depth study of the major theoretical issues in criminology.  Deals extensively with issues of crime causation.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing statistical data related to crime causation
Utilizing academic writing styles for criminology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in debates on crime causation theories
Collaborating with peers on criminological research projects
Participating in class discussions on criminological issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Formulating research questions on crime causation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for writing intensive assignments
Leading group discussions on criminological theories
Organizing research materials for criminological projects
Taking initiative in exploring new criminological theories

courseDescription: This course explores the topic  of homicide in the U.S.  It includes a discussion of the types of homicide, historical patterns and trends, and characteristics of offenders and victims.  A variety of theoretical frameworks are utilized to examine homicide at micro and macro levels.  In-depth examination of specific types of homicide is included.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective report writing on homicide cases
Ability to present complex data to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Utilizing theoretical frameworks for understanding crime
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in solving homicide cases

courseDescription: This course explores the topic of serial offenders, also referred to as repeat offenders, recidivists, and career criminals.  The course begins with an overview and discussion of patterns of crime, followed by a discussion of relevant theoretical perspectives.  We also discuss profiling and the role it can play in the investigation of serial crimes.  Next, we move into modules devoted to specific types of crime (arson, rape, homicide, etc.), and discuss the research on serial offenders in each group.   Finally, prevention, as well as social policy issues, are addressed.

Students work in groups to plan, design, and carry out a research project.  Final papers which report the results for the study are presented in a formal research seminar.  The projects reflect knowledge gained from undergraduate work and training received in STATÂ 130M and SOCÂ 337.

The study of sociological and social-psychological explanations of drug-using behaviors and of legal and medical control of drugs.  Topics include changes in the legal status of drugs, cross-cultural and historical variations in the control of drugs, and social epidemiology of drug use in contemporary society.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding legal and medical control of drugs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing changes in legal status of drugs
Evaluating historical variations in drug control
Interpreting sociological data on drug use

courseDescription: This is a service learning course designed to study how the emerging field of community justice, a neighborhood-based strategy, can reduce crime and improve public safety by investing in social, human and cultural capital.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Root cause analysis of community issues

courseDescription: This course examines the laws of the workplace from a sociological and issue-driven approach considering two perspectives â both employer and employee. Relevant laws are identified, explored and made relevant through examples of their application in real-world situations. Sometimes the wisdom of these laws will be challenged; students will be encouraged to raise questions about a lawâs utility, justice or fairness, whether in principle or in application.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal issues in the workplace
Application of laws in real-world scenarios
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Questioning the utility, justice, and fairness of laws
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of laws from employer and employee perspectives
Proposing solutions to improve workplace laws
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group projects on legal case studies

courseTitle: Women, Sex Discrimination and the Law
courseDescription: This course introduces students to legal issues which specifically affect women and examines historical attitudes that have been used to justify differential treatment of women.  It explores various legal approaches used to achieve equal protection under the law and examines a variety of specific topics such as:  the equal protection analysis; Title VII and Title IX and their relationship to sex discrimination; affirmative action; and reproductive freedom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Title VII and Title IX laws
Knowledge of affirmative action policies in relation to sex discrimination
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with diverse stakeholders on gender equality issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of sex discrimination cases
Analyzing historical legal attitudes towards women
Identifying legal strategies for achieving equal protection for women
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on gender equality in legal contexts
Organizing advocacy campaigns for women's rights
Implementing legal strategies for combating sex discrimination

courseDescription: Examines historical and contemporary theories and research on African-Americans, criminal behavior and the administration of justice.  Selected topics will include African-American perspectives, the death penalty, victimization, police brutality, and justice systems in Africa and the Caribbean.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis for criminal justice studies
Utilizing statistical software for analyzing crime data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings to diverse audiences
Engaging in discussions on race, crime, and justice issues
Collaborating with peers on group projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and contemporary theories on African-Americans and criminal behavior
Critically evaluating justice systems in Africa and the Caribbean
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on sensitive topics
Managing time effectively for research and writing assignments
Coordinating research projects on African-American perspectives in criminal justice

courseDescription: This course will examine the intersectionality of race, ethnicity, crime, justice and the operation of the criminal justice system and will critically assess controversial issues surrounding race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. Students will discuss contemporary social justice issues as they relate to race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. The theoretical frameworks that explain the intersection between race, ethnicity, crime and justice will be examined. The course will also investigate the broad range of policy issues and recommendations impacting communities of color and the administration of criminal and social justice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Critical analysis of criminal justice data
Understanding policy impact on communities of color
Theoretical frameworks application to real-world scenarios
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions on social justice issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical frameworks to practical situations
Evaluating policy recommendations for impact on communities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on race and justice topics
Collaborating with peers on research projects

courseDescription: This course examines the impact of diversity, culture, and ethnic origin in criminal justice organizations.  The course is designed to better prepare students to meet the challenge of diversity in criminal justice organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cultural sensitivity in technology implementation
Utilization of diversity in technology solutions for criminal justice organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of diversity impact on organizational policies
Identification and mitigation of bias in decision-making processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating inclusive environments in criminal justice organizations
Implementing diversity initiatives in leadership roles

courseDescription: This course deals with the major substantive concepts involved in American criminal law, including development of criminal law, elements of criminal liability, defenses against criminal responsibility, and descriptions and definitions of specific offenses.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of American criminal law concepts
Knowledge of elements of criminal liability
Familiarity with defenses against criminal responsibility
Ability to describe and define specific criminal offenses
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on case analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of legal principles to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex legal issues

courseTitle: Criminal Justice Systems Around the World
courseDescription: The study of criminal justice systems around the world in order to understand how criminal behavior is defined and responded to in various cultures.  Cultural differences will be highlighted in order to recognize that definitions of and responses to crimes closely reflect the cultures in which they exist.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of criminal justice systems
Critical evaluation of cultural influences on crime
Identifying global trends in criminal behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on cultural differences in criminal justice
Managing diverse viewpoints in criminal justice debates

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective report writing in law enforcement
Conflict resolution in criminal justice settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk assessment in criminal justice decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Policy development and implementation in criminal justice agencies

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Oral presentation skills for court testimony

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Networking with experts in the field

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Criminal Justice
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
A study of various definitions and forms of deviant behavior, theoretical explanations of causes of deviant behavior, and the impact of deviant behavior on society and the individual.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching and analyzing data on deviant behavior
Utilizing statistical software for data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on deviant behavior to a diverse audience
Collaborating with peers on research projects related to deviant behavior
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating various theories on the causes of deviant behavior
Critically analyzing the impact of deviant behavior on society and individuals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on theories of deviant behavior
Organizing and managing research projects on deviant behavior

courseDescription: An in-depth study of the major theoretical issues in criminology.  Deals extensively with issues of crime causation.

The study of sociological and social psychological explanations of drug-using behaviors and of legal and medical control of drugs.  Topics include changes in the legal status of drugs, cross-cultural and historical variations in the control of drugs, and social epidemiology of drug use in contemporary society.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding legal and medical control of drugs
Cross-cultural and historical variations in drug control
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing sociological explanations of drug-using behaviors
Presenting research findings on drug use
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing changes in legal status of drugs
Evaluating sociological and social psychological theories on drug use
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research data on drug use

courseDescription: Examines historical and contemporary theories and research on African-Americans, criminal behavior and the administration of justice.  Selected topics will include African-American perspectives, the death penalty, victimization, police brutality, and justice systems in Africa and the Caribbean.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ethical considerations in criminal justice research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with diverse perspectives on criminal justice issues
Effective communication with stakeholders in the justice system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of criminal justice policies
Analyzing data on crime rates and justice outcomes
Identifying systemic issues in the criminal justice system
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on race and justice
Organizing research projects on criminal behavior
Advocating for social justice in legal systems

courseDescription: This course deals with the major substantive concepts involved in American criminal law, including development of criminal law, elements of criminal liability, defenses against criminal responsibility, and descriptions and definitions of specific offenses.

courseTitle: Criminal Justice Systems Around the World
courseDescription: The study of criminal justice systems around the world in order to understand how criminal behavior is defined and responded to in various cultures.  Cultural differences will be highlighted in order to recognize that definitions of and responses to crimes closely reflect the cultures in which they exist.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of different criminal justice systems worldwide
Research and data analysis skills in criminal justice context
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of findings on cultural differences in criminal justice systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cultural influences on crime definitions
Analyzing responses to crimes based on cultural contexts
Identifying patterns in global criminal justice systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on cultural diversity in criminal justice systems
Organizing research projects on international legal systems

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective report writing in criminal justice
Conflict resolution in law enforcement scenarios

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conflict resolution in criminal justice settings

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Criminal Justice
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of criminal justice literature
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in selecting research topic

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Criminal Justice
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of criminal justice literature
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in selecting research topic

courseDescription: An in-depth study of the major theoretical issues in criminology.  The course deals extensively with issues of crime causation, the way theory shapes and informs the study of crime and related social issues, and the relationship between theory, research, and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Theory application in research and practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of crime causation theories
Analyzing the impact of theory on research outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading discussions on criminological theory

courseDescription: An analysis of the criminal justice system with an emphasis on the decision-making responsibilities of its officials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Information security in law enforcement databases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse stakeholders in the criminal justice system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision-making under uncertainty in criminal justice scenarios
Critical evaluation of evidence in criminal investigations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning in law enforcement operations

courseDescription: This course examines the many ways in which violence against women functions as an agent of social control.  Violence is viewed on a continuum in order to determine how a variety of acts contribute to the subordination of women.  Specific types of violence are explored including:  wife assault, rape, incest, sexual harassment and pornography.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of forensic evidence collection in cases of violence against women
Knowledge of digital communication tools for reporting abuse
Awareness of privacy and security measures in online safety resources
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and active listening in supporting survivors of violence against women
Effective communication with diverse stakeholders including law enforcement and social services
Conflict resolution skills in sensitive situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of societal norms contributing to violence against women
Analyzing data on prevalence and impact of different forms of violence
Developing intervention strategies based on case studies and research findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating community outreach programs to raise awareness on violence against women
Leading advocacy campaigns for policy change and legal reform
Managing resources efficiently for support services for survivors

courseDescription: A study of society's response to crime through its use of institutional and noninstitutional corrections.  Topics include inmate culture, correction officer behavior and community corrections programs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of institutional and noninstitutional corrections systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with inmates and staff
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of correctional officers
Implementing and monitoring community corrections programs

courseDescription: Students gain first-hand experience in professional settings which are deemed appropriate given their academic background and career objectives.  Students are required to complete a research project that corresponds to their specific internship placement
Advanced seminars on selected topics in criminal justice.  Topics will vary by semester.

courseDescription: Thesis hours.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
